description: As advocates for free speech, we can't help but see a certain irony in the attack President Donald Trump is mounting on social media organizations: Egged on by some of his supporters, including Missouri Sen. Trump's executive order takes aim at the protections Congress gave internet providers in 1996, when the internet was in its relative infancy.
text:
As advocates for free speech, we can't help but see a certain irony in the
attack President Donald Trump is mounting on social media organizations: Egged
on by some of his supporters, including Missouri Sen. Josh Hawley, Trump on
Thursday signed an executive order that he said is designed to curtail broad
protections granted to internet platform providers by Section 230 of the
Communications Decency Act.

In fact, the president is taking aim at the First Amendment rights of private
companies to engage in their own free speech. At a White House signing
ceremony, Trump claimed that he and other conservatives have been victims of
"censorship" by social media providers. This from a supernova of the
Twittersphere who by the latest count has published 50,000 times under the
handle @realDonaldTrump.

What prompted Trump to strike out at what he calls "censorship" by social
media companies was a decision by Twitter to fact check one of his tweets and
label it "misleading."

In doing so, Twitter did not muzzle the president but instead exercised its
editorial discretion. That's protected by the First Amendment.

Trump's executive order takes aim at the protections Congress gave internet
providers in 1996, when the internet was in its relative infancy. To put it in
perspective: Mark Zuckerberg was 12 and it would be another eight years before
he launched Facebook from his Harvard dorm room.

Section 230 gives internet platforms a legal immunity that traditional
publishers don't enjoy by decreeing that internet service providers and
bloggers cannot be held responsible for comments posted by users of their
sites. Lawmakers believed internet platforms opened public discourse to a
multitude of voices and feared they would be strangled in their cribs if they
were forced to defend against a lawsuit every time they failed to remove an
intemperate post. Although Congress hoped social media platforms would use
their immunity to remove harmful content, the law Congress wrote did not
require it.

DIGITAL WEEDS

Along with the thousand flowers -- times many, many more -- that have bloomed
on the internet, so have many noxious weeds. Social media have become a vector
for viruses almost as dangerous as the one that causes COVID-19:
Disinformation can be a democracy-killer, the more so when it's spread by
world leaders whose jobs make them role models.

The president's penchant for inaccuracies has been well-catalogued by others
but recently, he has used Twitter to revive a whopper that had even some of
his conservative allies shaking their heads in dismay, reviving a long-
discredited tale that links former U.S. Representative-turned-MSNBC host Joe
Scarborough to the accidental death of a young woman who worked in his
congressional office.

Under intense pressure over the defamatory Scarborough tweet and with the
staffer's widower begging Twitter to remove it, Twitter took action -- but not
on that issue. Instead, Twitter fact-checked a tweet in which the president
claimed that California's mail-in ballot procedure would open the door to
widespread election fraud. The fact-check label, which provided readers with a
link to additional information so they could make their own decisions about
the truth, led the president to sign the executive order targeting Twitter --
and, potentially, other social media platforms -- for exercising editorial
judgment.

The irony is that the libel umbrella Trump wants to snatch away is the only
reason that Twitter would leave a false and defamatory tweet like the
Scarborough allegation untouched; without section 230, Twitter would be
treated like a traditional publisher, such as a newspaper, and would risk
liability if it didn't take the president's tweet down.

SOCIAL MEDIA NEWS SOURCE

With the death of so many local papers and radio stations, readers --
particularly in rural areas -- rely more and more on social media for news,
but social media make it hard to distinguish reliable news sources from
pajama-clad amateurs. Combine that with information overload and the many and
devious sources of disinformation and it's no wonder democracy is in danger of
overdosing on cynicism.

Having supplanted traditional publishers as citizens' primary source of
information, social media platforms are right to begin acting like mature
corporate citizens. The only problem is that they seem to take two steps
backward for every one in advance.

Consider Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg's attempt to distance his company from
the controversy over Twitter's fact-checking: "I just believe strongly that
Facebook shouldn't be the arbiter of truth of everything that people say
online." But shouldn't the most powerful media company in the world -- and
that's what Facebook is -- devote some resources to prevent its platform from
being used to infect public discourse with viral lies?

A responsible corporation may not be able to ascertain the Platonic ideal of
truth. But it should be able to distinguish an outright falsehood, like the
doctored video of Nancy Pelosi that Facebook refused to take down.

The First Amendment is designed to protect political speech, especially speech
that criticizes and questions those in power. It is not designed as a shield
for malicious falsehoods. Our law punishes defamatory falsehoods to ensure
that public discourse maintains an anchor in truth, for without it, public
discourse becomes meaningless.

If the president really wants to get rid of section 230's protections of
internet providers, it means the same defamation laws that keep traditional
publishers from turning their pages over to the loudest and most outrageous
voices will apply to internet platforms as well. The person most likely to be
silenced: Trump himself.

Kathy Kiely is the Lee Hills Chair in Free Press Studies at the Missouri
School of Journalism; Lyrissa Lidsky is dean of the University of Missouri
School of Law.

title: Commentary: Is the Tweeter-in-Chief trying to shut himself up?
html:
As advocates for free speech, we can't help but see a certain irony in the attack President Donald Trump is mounting on social media organizations: Egged on by some of his supporters, including Missouri Sen. Josh Hawley, Trump on Thursday signed an executive order that he said is designed to curtail broad protections granted to internet platform providers by Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act.

In fact, the president is taking aim at the First Amendment rights of private companies to engage in their own free speech. At a White House signing ceremony, Trump claimed that he and other conservatives have been victims of "censorship" by social media providers. This from a supernova of the Twittersphere who by the latest count has published 50,000 times under the handle @realDonaldTrump.

What prompted Trump to strike out at what he calls "censorship" by social media companies was a decision by Twitter to fact check one of his tweets and label it "misleading."

In doing so, Twitter did not muzzle the president but instead exercised its editorial discretion. That's protected by the First Amendment.

Trump's executive order takes aim at the protections Congress gave internet providers in 1996, when the internet was in its relative infancy. To put it in perspective: Mark Zuckerberg was 12 and it would be another eight years before he launched Facebook from his Harvard dorm room.

Section 230 gives internet platforms a legal immunity that traditional publishers don't enjoy by decreeing that internet service providers and bloggers cannot be held responsible for comments posted by users of their sites. Lawmakers believed internet platforms opened public discourse to a multitude of voices and feared they would be strangled in their cribs if they were forced to defend against a lawsuit every time they failed to remove an intemperate post. Although Congress hoped social media platforms would use their immunity to remove harmful content, the law Congress wrote did not require it.

DIGITAL WEEDS

Along with the thousand flowers — times many, many more — that have bloomed on the internet, so have many noxious weeds. Social media have become a vector for viruses almost as dangerous as the one that causes COVID-19: Disinformation can be a democracy-killer, the more so when it's spread by world leaders whose jobs make them role models.

The president's penchant for inaccuracies has been well-catalogued by others but recently, he has used Twitter to revive a whopper that had even some of his conservative allies shaking their heads in dismay, reviving a long-discredited tale that links former U.S. Representative-turned-MSNBC host Joe Scarborough to the accidental death of a young woman who worked in his congressional office.

Under intense pressure over the defamatory Scarborough tweet and with the staffer's widower begging Twitter to remove it, Twitter took action — but not on that issue. Instead, Twitter fact-checked a tweet in which the president claimed that California's mail-in ballot procedure would open the door to widespread election fraud. The fact-check label, which provided readers with a link to additional information so they could make their own decisions about the truth, led the president to sign the executive order targeting Twitter — and, potentially, other social media platforms — for exercising editorial judgment.

The irony is that the libel umbrella Trump wants to snatch away is the only reason that Twitter would leave a false and defamatory tweet like the Scarborough allegation untouched; without section 230, Twitter would be treated like a traditional publisher, such as a newspaper, and would risk liability if it didn't take the president's tweet down.

SOCIAL MEDIA NEWS SOURCE

With the death of so many local papers and radio stations, readers — particularly in rural areas — rely more and more on social media for news, but social media make it hard to distinguish reliable news sources from pajama-clad amateurs. Combine that with information overload and the many and devious sources of disinformation and it's no wonder democracy is in danger of overdosing on cynicism.

Having supplanted traditional publishers as citizens' primary source of information, social media platforms are right to begin acting like mature corporate citizens. The only problem is that they seem to take two steps backward for every one in advance.

Consider Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg's attempt to distance his company from the controversy over Twitter's fact-checking: "I just believe strongly that Facebook shouldn't be the arbiter of truth of everything that people say online." But shouldn't the most powerful media company in the world — and that's what Facebook is — devote some resources to prevent its platform from being used to infect public discourse with viral lies?

A responsible corporation may not be able to ascertain the Platonic ideal of truth. But it should be able to distinguish an outright falsehood, like the doctored video of Nancy Pelosi that Facebook refused to take down.

The First Amendment is designed to protect political speech, especially speech that criticizes and questions those in power. It is not designed as a shield for malicious falsehoods. Our law punishes defamatory falsehoods to ensure that public discourse maintains an anchor in truth, for without it, public discourse becomes meaningless.

If the president really wants to get rid of section 230's protections of internet providers, it means the same defamation laws that keep traditional publishers from turning their pages over to the loudest and most outrageous voices will apply to internet platforms as well. The person most likely to be silenced: Trump himself.

Kathy Kiely is the Lee Hills Chair in Free Press Studies at the Missouri School of Journalism; Lyrissa Lidsky is dean of the University of Missouri School of Law.
